comments.body: Have you (or anyone else) tested what happens when `ownca_not_after` lies in the past? Does OpenSSL complain, or just signs the certificate? I'm wondering because if it complains / dies / ..., this test will start failing in a year. :)

@felixfontein good point! I just went ahead and tested it, the certificate is created without problems when choosing a validity period in the past. It even succeeds when notAfter lies before notBefore.
Awesome! That's what I was hoping for! :)

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +121,125 @@    provider: ownca
    ownca_not_before: 20181023133742Z
    ownca_not_after: 20191023133742Z
    path: "{{ output_dir }}/ownca_cert3.pem"
    csr_path: "{{ output_dir }}/csr.csr"

comments.body:
```suggestion
        type: '{{ item }}'
        cipher: auto
        passphrase: Test123
```
to be pedantic :) regarding the playbooks from https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/59039
It needs to be further below, when creating the private key for the Own CA. I've added it there.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +444,448 @@      openssl_privatekey:
        path: '{{ output_dir }}/privatekey_{{ item }}.pem'
        type: '{{ item }}'
      loop:
        - Ed25519

comments.body:
```suggestion
        select_crypto_backend: '{{ select_crypto_backend }}'
        common_name: openssl.local
        privatekey_passphrase: Test123
        basic_constraints: CA:TRUE
        key_usage: cRLSign,keyCertSign
```
or something like this to correspond to the issue. And the following tests too :)
This also has to be moved down. I added `key_usage` below, since the rest was already there.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +455,459 @@        subject:
          commonName: www.ansible.com
        select_crypto_backend: '{{ select_crypto_backend }}'
      loop:
        - Ed25519
